discourse_list.title: A Large Complex DAO: reducing the human footprint

content.content: Threads like this are a clear symptom of a DAO that has grown far too large, unnecessarily complex and unsustainably reliant on the integrity of some humans.
content.GPT-summary: The post discusses the issues with a large and complex DAO and how it can become unsustainable. The author is explaining their proposal to reduce the human footprint, while a third party is giving constructive criticism of the proposal.

content.content: So is the best action to shrink Maker to a smaller simpler footprint, making it less economically relevant?

Eumenes:  shrink Maker to a smaller simpler footprint   Yes. Consolidate and automate.     Eumenes:  making it less economically relevant   No. The size of the DAO is not correlated to its economic impact.

content.content: That is an interesting assumption.  Would you have any empirical support backing it?
Sure. Uniswap v1, v2 and v3 have nearly zero DAO control and the protocols are essentially the backbone of DeFi.

ChrisBlec:  Uniswap v1, v2 and v3 have nearly zero DAO control and the protocols are essentially the backbone of DeFi   I agree that Uniswap is a backbone of DeFi, but otherwise it hardly seems like an example that Maker should want to emulate. Uniswap Labs is a completely centralised entity that calls the shots for the protocol, right down to things like acquiring other companies to add NFTs,  censoring specific tokens on the frontend and making myriad unilateral changes to the underlying protocol. I get the argument that Maker’s governance footprint should shrink, but let’s not follow Uniswap down a path of sham decentralisation.

content.content: I think @ChrisBlec is coming from the perspective that our ultimate goal is for smart contracts to be smart enough to replace work that’s done by a hired workforce.  People fight and when there are too many opinions, politics eventually dominate.  Smart contracts just follow rules and do what they’re supposed to do.  When they fail, they are fixed and rebuilt to be better.  I agree that we shouldn’t forget the vision and promise of this industry. I think @lyt is speaking from a realist’s perspective that we aren’t there yet and that the R&D to get there requires people in many different roles for the foreseeable future. I’m sympathetic to both views and hope we as a community will be able to set aside differences and focus on building solutions to the challenges we face.  But the fundamental question you both ask is important.  Who is truly critical to the protocol?  (would we be performing any worse if we had just stuck with a paid PECU and Risk team?). What roles are unnecessary or of lower value than their cost?  And where might more people be actually causing harm by distraction, conflict, and discouragement?  I don’t expect there to be any consensus on this but we can continue to examine, reflect, and hopefully improve the effectiveness of the workforce.

content.content: Doo_StableLab:  I feel the discussion has gone a bit offtopic…   With this I whole-heartedly agree, and will be making an attempt below to get the discussion back on track, as I very firmly believe this to be the only discussion worth having at this moment in time…     Doo_StableLab:  …as this focuses on “Mandated Actors Neutrality Discussion” Maybe it’s best to discuss economic impact & number of people in the org in a separate thread.   With all due respect (truly), I humbly yet whole-heartedly disagree… The original thread was for the “Mandated Actors Neutrality Discussion” (I’m quoting you there, but of course that was also the very title of that thread)… On the other hand, this spin-off thread (titled “A Large Complex DAO: reducing the human footprint”) is very much for “[discussing] economic impact & number of people in the org”… And this one is only related to that one insofar as that one, and its general tone & goings-on, serves as an example of what this thread is attempting to bring to light… @ChrisBlec please correct me if the above is wrong, and/or please jump in and reply-to/rebut the following… I don’t mean to speak on your behalf…  Now, I can see that many Makers (is that what we call ourselves?) seem to be very concerned about this thing we’re all calling “growth”, which in the comments above has also been referred to as “economic impact”… I can also see that many Makers think we can grow now, and also that we must grow now, in order to be “economically impactful” now… I submit that this kind of near-sighted thinking (now now now) is not only a case of ‘putting the cart before the horse’, but that it is, in fact, a disastrous case of it which could do (and possibly/arguably already is doing) irreparable damage to Maker in the mid-to-long term… Before I begin, I’d like to tag @Eumenes, as I believe this will be relevant to your interests… Here I present two examples, one “legacy” example (@lyt wants to talk about Walmart, let’s talk about Walmart) and one “modern” (aka ‘digital age’) example…  Walmart https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walmart Walmart started with one store in the early 1960’s in a small region of Arkansas. After nearly a decade, Walmart had grown to 38 stores and one regional distribution center to service them. At that point, they had 1,500 employees total (HQ employees, yes, but also in-store sales associates, warehouse workers, etc) and sales of $44.2 million… Which in today’s dollars would be roughly $333M…  Aside: To reiterate, that’s one-third of a billion ‘today dollars’ being managed/overseen at the time by maybe, what, 150 people? (one-tenth of the above-stated 1,500 employees)… So there’s your example of a small/agile group with an outsized “economic impact”…  Now, yes, Walmart went on to be a globally recognized powerhouse of a retail brand worth hundreds of billions ($331B in the U.S. alone in 2019 – aka pre-pandemic), but they didn’t just pop into existence that way… It took them decades to get there, and here’s the really really very important bit: In those early days I described above, they stayed small, relegated to a small region of the deep U.S. south, and grew themselves organically… It wasn’t until they had a solid business model and a well-functioning system in place (a few dozen stores and a regional distribution center to support them) that they were then able to really expand (aka “grow”) to have the super-charged “economic impact” we see today…  Facebook https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Facebook Spoiler alert: I’m about to make basically the exact same case for Facebook in the 2000’s that I just made for Walmart in the '60s… In fact, I’m also just copy/pasting the same text I used for Walmart as a starting template for this Facebook example… Facebook started in the early 2000’s at one university. Now, where Walmart took nearly a decade to build and prove their economic model, Facebook would only take about a year (welcome to the digital age!) to increase from one ivy league school to four, and then to all the ivy league schools, and then to most colleges in the U.S. and Canada… But it would still be another two years before they would open the platform to the general public, and another year after that for Microsoft to buy-in at a roughly $15B valuation… Or $21B in today’s dollars… So, not quite early-days Walmart money, but still not bad considering they did it in about one-third the time… And of course Facebook went on to be a globally recognized powerhouse of a social brand worth hundreds of billions ($200B in 2014), but they didn’t just pop into existence that way… It took them about a decade to get there, and here’s the really really very important bit: In those early days I described above, they stayed small, relegated to just colleges in North America, and grew themselves organically… It wasn’t until they had a solid business model and a well-functioning system in place (a website for college kids to socially interact with each other) that they were then able to really expand (aka “grow”) to have the super-charged “economic impact” we see today…  So what’s your point, MWOW? My point is this: Maker launched very late in 2017, so we’re now only four and a half years into this thing (and only a year from the Foundation handing the whole thing over to us BTW!) and we’re at, what, $7B today counting both MKR & DAI…? And if you account for the recent macro economic downturn (Facebook was born during the dotcom-bubble recovery, lucky them!) and the fact that the blockchain and DAOs in particular are/were still quite new (meaning Maker has had to largely pioneer the concept for themselves*) then we have to grade this on a curve and say that we’re still very much in the early days here, like Facebook during (arguably near the end of, to be sure) its “college years”…  * Versus Facebook, where all they did was build a website (not a novel concept in 2004) focused on teens / twenty-somethings interacting with each other socially (not a novel concept in all of human history)…  Meaning what, exactly? Meaning: Calm down and get some perspective, dang it!!! Also meaning: We need need need to take the time, right now before it’s too late, to do what Walmart and Facebook and many many other “economically impactful” global entities have all done: Build something really great on a relatively small scale first, get it perfect while it’s still a manageable size, then grow it to massive scale… And I’m sorry, but I think anyone else here* calling for “[Maker] to spend all available resources on growth [right now]” are just plain wrong… It’s near-sighted and, frankly, unhealthy for the ecosystem…and, also frankly, kinda greedy…  * I’m looking at Makers like @krzkaczor @superTricycle & @Hasu from the latter comments of this discussion… And please know that I’m tagging you to get your eyes on this, and so I can hear your rebuttals… I can see the surrounding paragraphs may come across as a bit standoff-ish as I read this back, but I’m sticking with it as I think the reality of the situation may be that we’re all in a bit of a standoff at the moment…  I mean, think about it: You all want to make decisions about “hyper-growth” (or anything else) right now using a fledgling, somewhat ill-defined, clearly not-entirely-healthy decision-making process…? What?? If you’re walking on a path and see that you’re likely headed off a cliff in the distance, you don’t start sprinting forward! You’ve gotta stop and assess the situation, and seriously consider whether maybe going back and taking a different fork in the road somewhere might not be the better option… And yeah, I recognize that Maker is no longer profitable right now, and tightening one’s belt is never a fun prospect… But can we please prioritize stabilizing economically while growing governance participation, codifying the governance structure, and generally just getting our ducks in a row first? Get the DAO into a strong, healthy state before we start sprinting into the future? I mean, time really is on our side here… At least, that’s how I see it… Thank you for reading, whoever read this. I appreciate your time and attention.
